editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: THE Epi≈øtle Dedicatory. To the Right Honourable, Learned and Religious, Sir Thomas Burnet of Leis, Knight and Baronett, and one of their Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Privy Council; for the Kingdom of Scotland; Grace, Peace, and all Happine≈øs, both Temporal and Eternal.
div.p: IT is the Promi≈øe of the All-Glorious God, to Honour tho≈øe that Honour him; there be four ≈øpecial ways, whereby God Honours Men.

Fir≈øt, When he rai≈øeth them out of nothing, wor≈øe than nothing, yea, from the very depth of Hell, to a height of Heavenly Honour, Happine≈øs and Holine≈øs in Chri≈øt Je≈øus, whereby he makes them more Excellent than their Neighbours, Prov. 12.26. more Excellent, not in degrees only, but in kind; more Excellent in their Birth, for they are Born again of the Word, and of the Spirit; more Excellent in their Thoughts, more Excellent in their Affections, more Excellent in their Practices, more Excellent in their Lives, in Regard of Gods Favour towards them; and more Excellent
in their Death, their Death is ≈øweet to them: All True Chri≈øtians are truly Right Honourable, and Truly Royal: They are Loyal Subjects, and a Royal Prie≈øt-hood, 1 Pet. 2.9. They are really the lowe≈øt, yet the highe≈øt People, Exod. 19.6. Lowe≈øt in their own Sen≈øe, highe≈øt in Gods ≈øight, Rev. 1.6. and 5.10.

Secondly, God Honours Men, when he gives them Hearts to ≈øerve him, in a Faithful and Fruitful Subjection to his Will. The Service of God, is not only Duty, but al≈øo our Priviledge and Preferment. Hence Theodo≈øius Gloryed more in that he was a Servant of Chri≈øt, than being Emperour of the Ea≈øt.
Thirdly, God Honours Men, when he ra≈øes Men to places of Eminency above others: And makes them Faithful, in employing their power for God, and Piou≈øly prudent in their publick Deportment.

Fourthly, But the highe≈øt Honour ≈øhall be hereafter in Heaven, when the Saints ≈øhall be filled brim full, with Grace and Glory. We cannot Honour God, until he hath Honoured us: We cannot give glory to God, until we have received glory from him; becau≈øe he fir≈øt Honours us; Grace is Glory, 2 Cor. 3.18.

Sir, God hath Honoured your Family, with the True≈øt Honour in Chri≈øt, Rom. 8.30. Your Ance≈øtors have been Right Honourable,
for Piety, Virtue, Religion and Zeal to Gods Glory; and God hath made you a Honourable Branch, of that Honourable Family, and hath given you a Heart to Honour him again. Some Families are valued from Antiquity, who can pretend Title to Religion or Virtue in them≈øelves or Ance≈øtors; but your Honour is truly valuable on both accounts, and indeed from Religion, and Exemplary practice of Godline≈øs, the Ble≈ø≈øing on Families and Per≈øons, is to be expected. Wickedne≈øs and Debauchery, hath lain ≈øo long on ≈øome Families, as a Moth, until they are altogether gangren'd; and as the Degeneracy of ≈øome Families in Religion and Morals, is too, too palpable, it's to be likewi≈øe feared, their Extirpation may be as Con≈øpicuous, and it ought to be Matter of Humiliation, that Impiety hath been ≈øo Predominant, without Parallel, in the late Reigns; From the inexcu≈øable Incouragement at the Helm; that the mo≈øt Con≈øiderable Families in the≈øe Nations, have been Sullyed with the blacke≈øt Stains of Vice, ≈øo that Morality hath been accounted pedantry, and Religion Bafouned and Ridiculed. And it mu≈øt be allowed the Glory, as well as the Mercy of ≈øome, who have not been carryed away in ≈øuch a Deluge. And your Honour by the ≈øpecial Conduct of Providence, hath been pre≈øerved in your integrity,
as an Exemplary Stock to graft upon, for the future Propagation of Religion.

The≈øe following Sheets, being a Collection of the private Meditations of a Gentleman, Born and Educated in the Kingdom of Scotland, near to your Honours Antient Mannor of Crathis; In his Solitude, when by Providence, he was re≈øtrained from the Exerci≈øe of his Talent, in the way of his Profe≈ø≈øion and Education; and only intended for the u≈øe of him≈øelf, and Family. But whil≈øt in his Confinement, he was vi≈øited by ≈øome Chri≈øtian Friends, as well of Sacred, as Civil Profe≈ø≈øion, and the≈øe Sheets coming occa≈øionally to be by them viewed and approved of; The Author was Importuned to Print the ≈øame, as containing many particulars, which might tend to the Advancement of Religion. But for ≈øeveral Rea≈øons, he was Aver≈øe; as Fir≈øt, his then Circum≈øtances could not bear the Charge of the Pre≈øs; Secondly, He hath truly ob≈øerved, that the ≈øincere Affections to Religion in Life and Practice, is ≈øo decayed, that whatever is wrote on that Subject, unle≈øs varni≈øhed under the Name of ≈øome Author Eminently in Vogue, the ≈øame is implicitly vilified; and he intending not to be known, and con≈øidering, if known, his Name might not be Authentick, to give Reputation to
the Truth of the Writing, however valuable in it ≈øelf. Thirdly, That as Books are valued not ≈øo much for the matter they contain, as the Fame of the Author, or Patrociny of ≈øome Eminent Per≈øon, he found him≈øelf at a lo≈øs, to whom to Dedicate, fearing in this Degeneracy of zeal for God, his Dedication might be con≈øtrued avarice, rather than de≈øire of a Patrone.

The≈øe Sheets lying thus in their Swadling-Cloaths, and like to peri≈øh in Darkne≈øs, and I being Familiarly acquainted with the Author, and finding that in them the mo≈øt Nervous parts of Practical Relegion, were Judiciou≈øly Treated and Methodized, I was induced from Zeal, in Advancing Religion, to Solicite the Authors Permi≈ø≈øion to Publi≈øh the≈øe Sheets; and the rather, for what was his Di≈øcouragement, in want of Patron, was my Encouragement, that I might Pre≈øume upon your Honours Favour on this behalf.

The Author having appo≈øitely Intituled this Treati≈øe (The Anatomy of Man) as being a Series of the whole State of Man, from his Creation, to his Eternal Re≈øt in Glory, and I having the Happine≈øs to be ≈øo well acquainted with your Honours zeal, for the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, and of your Knowledge in all the My≈øtical and Practical parts of Religion, your Serene Judgment
to di≈øtingui≈øh, and your Charity to Encourage good Intentions, and Indulge E≈øcapes, I could no where find a ≈øafer Sanctuary for (the Anatomy of Man) than in your Honours Protection. Neither could I, without the Violation of greate≈øt obligations, omit this Oblation to your Honour; and if I may be ju≈øtified from the fal≈øe Imputation of flattery, I can boldly aver, your Honour is duly Intituled to ≈øuch Patrociny, not only from the long Series of your Judicious, Ju≈øt, and Honourable Ance≈øtors; but al≈øo from your own Exemplary E≈øpou≈øing, Protecting and Encouraging of Religion; and Con≈øtant, Holy, Affection to the Go≈øpel of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Therefore Right Honourable, through your gentle Hands, I commend this Treati≈øe to the World. It is not nece≈ø≈øary that I ≈øhould give it an account, why I ≈øeek ≈øo far from home! God hath wrought my Heart, to Love tho≈øe that Love him, and Honour tho≈øe that Honour him: And di≈øtance of Place, cannot Abridge my Duty. With all this, I would the World ≈øhould know, I am one, among≈øt tho≈øe many, who truly Honour you for your Virtues. In Te≈øtimony whereof, I make this Dedication to your Worthy Name, and Honourable Per≈øon, which I be≈øeech you to accept of, as an
Acknowledgment of that Debt I owe, and the unfeigned de≈øire I have of your Souls Welfare.

Let the≈øe Sheets as hopeful Twins, find ≈øhelter under your Wings, and Protection under your Roof. If your Honour approve of them, and find in them the Anatome of the Title, and that they may be of u≈øe to the pre≈øent, and after Generations, your Countenance is implored thereunto as a Lu≈øtre, which in ≈øome mea≈øure, may ≈øupply Omi≈ø≈øions or Defects of the Author. And as he is ≈øond of your Patrociny, and will gratefully acknowledge the Honour of it, I mu≈øt needs own my Renewed Obligations, in the Acceptance of this my Addre≈øs; and ≈øhall by Divine A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, never be wanting, to Wi≈øh and Pray for the Increa≈øe and Continuance of Grace, Honour, and Pro≈øperity to your ≈øelf, your Pious, Honourable Worthy, and Zealou≈øly Religious Lady, and Hopeful Succe≈ø≈øion, as the indi≈øpen≈øable Duty of,

closer.signed: Your Honour's mo≈øt Faithful and Humble Servant, ANDREW BURNETT.

div.head: THE EPISTLE TO THE READER.
div.p:
IF we con≈øider Man in his fir≈øt Creation, as Created in the Likene≈øs, and after the Image of God, Gen. 1.27. in Righteou≈øne≈øs, True Holine≈øs, and Knowledge, Eph. 4.24. Col. 1.10. whereby he was ≈øufficiently enabled to under≈øtand all things, nece≈ø≈øary for his own Happine≈øs, his Obedience to God, and Government of the Creatures; and that to him, were given all the Creatures for U≈øe, with Dominion over them, and that then all the Works of God were very good, Gen. 1.28, 31. when all the Creatures were in Amity among≈øt them≈øelves, and in Subjection to Man; when God delighted in Man, and was plea≈øed with all the Works of his own Hands; when the Creation admired the Maje≈øty of God, and paid Obedience
to Man; when all the Creation rejoyced together, and had Complacency in one another; when the Soveraign Ruled with Love, and Subjects obeyed with Fear; when greatne≈øs was without Envy, and Subjection without Contempt; when Beauty was without Pride, and Wealth without Covetou≈øne≈øs; when plea≈øure was without Lu≈øt, and Profit and Plenty, without Trouble or Sorrow; when each complyed with others, and there was no Repining; when all had enough, and none was under Reproach; when all were in Amity, and took plea≈øure in one another; when all enjoyed Content, and none exceeded his bounds; when all things were plea≈øant, and nothing contemptible; when all things were u≈øeful, and nothing pernitious; When the Morning Stars Sung together, and all the Sons of God ≈øhouted for Joy, Job 38.7. When the Speech and Language of all the Creation, to the ends of the Earth, was to ≈øound out, and declare the glory of the mo≈øt High. P≈ø. 19.1, 2, 3.

When the unity of the Sons of God by Creation, was Like the Pretious Oyntment on the Beard, running down the Skirts of the Garments, fragrant and refre≈øhful, and as the Dew on the Mountains, bringing Nouri≈øhment to the Plants, P≈ø. 133. who could with-hold from crying out, O Lord, how excellent is thy Name in all the Earth,
thou art glorious in Holine≈øs, fearful in Prai≈øes, doing Wonders, P≈ø. 8.1, 2, 3. a Fountain of Gardens, a well of living Waters, and Streams of all fulne≈øs? Cant. 4.15. and with David, admire the free and Soveraign goodne≈øs of God, What is Man, that thou art mindful of him, and the Son of Man that thou vi≈øite≈øt him? For thou ha≈øt made him a little lower than the Angels, and ha≈øt Crowned him with Glory and Honour, thou ha≈øt given him to have Dominion over the works of thy Hands, thou ha≈øt put all things under his Feet, P≈ø. 8.4, to end.
Who could avoid to ≈øit down under this ≈øhadow with great delight, and find the Fruit plea≈øant to their Ta≈øt, and be ≈øick of Love? Cant. 2.2, 3, 5.

If on the other hand, we con≈øider that pale and di≈ømal Countenance of all things, under that woful Apo≈øtacy, and Spirit of Rebellion, again≈øt God in this our Day, That every Imagination of the Thoughts of Mans Heart, is only Evil continually, Gen. 6.5. That Man denyeth God, hath gone a≈øtray from him, is become filthy, that there is none that doth good, no not one, nor any that calleth on God, P≈ø. 14. to 5. That Man hath lifted up his Heels, and Revolted from his Maker. This is not found out by ≈øecret ≈øearch, but di≈øcovered in all his ≈øteps, ≈øince that Apo≈øtacy,
Man was Holine≈øs to the Lord, at his Creation in Gods Image, Jer. 2.3. but now is a Loath≈øom Batch of all filthine≈øs, From the Sole of the Foot, even unto the Head, there is no ≈øoundne≈øs in it, we are fall as an unclean thing, and all our Righteou≈øne≈øs are as filthy Rags, and we do all fade away as a Leaf, and our Iniquities like the Wind have taken us away, I≈ø. 1.6. ch. 64.6, 7.

As Man hath Revolted in Di≈øobedience from God, ≈øo we find a Revolt, Confu≈øion, and Apo≈øtacy among≈øt the Creatures, the Spirit of Di≈øobedience is ≈øo broke out among≈øt Men, that through the Pride and Voluptuous Appetite of Mens Hearts, the World is almo≈øt Degenerated into an a≈ø≈øumed Annarchy, of ≈øelf-intere≈øt, and preferrence, ≈øo that due Subjection is declined, unle≈øs con≈øtrained by force; and that among≈øt Men, fir≈øt, in D ‚Ä¢ me≈øtick, ≈øecondly in a publick Capacity, which is clearly proved by Scripture and Experience, Fir≈øt by Scripture, The Son Di≈øhonoureth the Father, the Daughter ri≈øeth up again≈øt the Mother, the Daughter in Law again≈øt the Mother in Law, a Mans Enemies are the Men of his own Hou≈øe, &c. Mic. 7.6, 7.

David was Per≈øecuted, and hunted like a Partridge by Saul his Father in Law, and had his Crown u≈øurped from him by his own Son Ab≈øolom, 2 Sam. 15. and Zenacherib King of A≈ø≈øyria,
was murdered by his own Sons, I≈ø. 37.38.

Doth not Ambition for Dominion, Covetou≈øne≈øs for gain, divide Relations? what Relation or Affinity, oblige Men beyond their pretended Intere≈øt? what Allyances or Treaties, tye Princes from U≈øurpation or Encroachments? may it not be too much charged on mo≈øt of the greate≈øt form on Earth, which was ≈øaid of Philip of Macedon, amicitias utilitate non fide colebat, his Intere≈øt, not his Promi≈øe obliged him.

Secondly, If we look on the World in re≈øpect of the Politick Con≈øtitution, what Nation, Country, or People ≈øhall we find quiet from Commotions, Di≈øturbances, Rebellions, or Mutinies, either from the Oppre≈ø≈øion, Tyranny, or U≈øurpation of the Soveraign, or the Murmurings, Jealou≈øies, and Mutinous, Unea≈øie, and Di≈øcontented Humours of the Subject? Doth not Judah vex Ephraim, and Ephraim envy Judah, I≈ø. 11.13. doth not the Church Complain, Servants have ruled over us, and none delivered out of their Hands, Kings are hanged up by their Hand, the faces of Elders were not Honoured? Lam. 5.8, 12.

Is not the whole World at Enmity, Nation again≈øt Nation, and Nations divided by inte≈øtine Wars, and Contentions? This Enmity is not only between Man and Man, but hath al≈øo infected the Bea≈øts of the Field,
Fi≈øh of the Sea, and fouls of the Air; whereas in Mans fir≈øt State, he had all of them given him for u≈øe, with Dominion over them; they are turned wild, run into Rebellion, and not to be ≈øubdued or made u≈øeful, but by force, and many are not only u≈øele≈øs, but de≈øtructive, and they al≈øo are at War among≈øt them≈øelves, de≈øtroying one another; ≈øo that in place of all the Sons of God, ≈øhouting together for Joy, as in the fir≈øt State, we now hear the noi≈øe of Wars, Malice, Envy and De≈øtruction; and whereas at fir≈øt, God looked on all that he had made, and it was very good, Gen. 1.31. afterwards for the Degeneracy thereof, It repented God, that he had made Man on the Earth, and it grieved him at his Heart, Gen. 6.6. and whereas all things were good when fir≈øt Created, and given to Man for u≈øe; the Scripture tells us, That the Friend≈øhip of the World is Enmity with God, and who≈øoever will be a Friend of the World, is the Enemy of God. If any Man love the World, the love of the Father is not in him, Ja. 4.4. 1 Jo. 2.15.

If then the Heavenly Harmony, Union, and joyful Shoutings of the Sons of God, was Ravi≈øhing and Refre≈øhful, even to ≈øitting down under that ≈øhadow with great delight, and being ≈øick of Love, when Man and the Creation was in its fir≈øt Integrity, when we look
on the black and defaced Countenance of Man and Creatures, defiled with all manner of Sin and Pollution, and the World with all Deformity of Wickedne≈ø≈øes and Contention, and being Branded with Gods di≈øplea≈øure.

How great rea≈øon have we with the Church to cry out, How is the Gold become Dim; How is the mo≈øt fine Gold changed? and with David to ≈øay, Wo is me, that I Sojourn in Me≈øech, and dwell in the Tents of Kedar? P≈ø. 120.5.

If the Soul of Righteous Lot, was grieved at the Iniquity of Sodom, how much more Rea≈øon have Men now adays, to grieve for that univer≈øal Deluge of Abominations, which overflow the whole, while earth in ≈øerious Reflection of Man in his Integrity, and the Beauty of the Creation, and the pre≈øent Degeneracy under Sin and Mi≈øery, and being Anxious to under≈øtand that My≈øtery, why the World once approved of God to be good, and given to Man, ≈øhould afterwards be ≈øtamped with Gods Cur≈øe and Di≈øplea≈øure, as in the foregoing Scripture, I was entertained with that of Eliphas the Temanite, Shall Mortal Man be more ju≈øt than God, ≈øhall a Man be more pure than his Maker, Job. 4.17. which lead me to enquire into the particular cau≈øes of this great Cata≈øtrophe, and to under≈øtand the meaning, together with the
Ju≈øtice of God, and the Mi≈øtery of his Love to believers, in Chri≈øt Je≈øus.

In this enquiry, I was led up to the Fountain of Gods bounty to Man, by which he was made in the likene≈øs of God in Righteou≈øne≈øs, true Holine≈øs, and Knowledge, according to the Image of him that Created him, and had the other Creatures given to him for u≈øe, with Dominion over them, under the Tenure of his Obedience, and under the Commination and A≈ø≈øurance of Death on his Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion.

I had no ≈øooner viewed the Happine≈øs of his fir≈øt E≈øtate, when I was led to the Record of his Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, by putting forth his Heart to Rebellion, and his Hands to the Tre≈øpa≈øs, and then found the Judgment entred again≈øt him, by which he was degraded of his Soveraignty, and Enmity was ≈øown between him and the Creatures, and the Earth accur≈øed for his ≈øake, Gen. 3.14. to 20.

And here with the Prophet, we may put the que≈øtion, is Man the Darling of the Creation, made lately in Gods own Image, and Lord of all the Creation? is he now a Servant, a Home-born Slave? why is he ≈øpoiled? The An≈øwer is in the Text, ha≈øt thou not procured this to thy ≈øelf, In that thou ha≈øt for≈øaken the Lord thy God? for my People have committed two Evils, they have for≈øaken me, the Fountain of Living Waters,
and hewed them≈øelves Ci≈øterns, broken Ci≈øterns, that can hold no Water, Jer. 2.11, 13, 14, 17.
And with the ≈øame Prophet we may cry out with A≈øtoni≈øhment, Be A≈øtoni≈øhed O Heavens, and be horribly afraid, be ye very de≈øolate, ≈øaith the Lord, Jer. 2.11.

And here is this Riddle re≈øolved, ≈øhall Mortal Man be more Ju≈øt than God? Shall Man be more pure than his Maker, Man hath for≈øaken God, and followed his own Inventions, therefore God mu≈øt be ju≈øt, to bring upon him the Judgment threatned, viz. the forfeiture of all his Priviledges, and make him ≈ømart under the folly of his own Devices. They hatch Cockatrice Eggs, and weave the Spiders Webb, he that eateth of their Eggs dyeth, and that which is cru≈øhed breaketh into a Viper, their Webb ≈øhall not become Garments, neither ≈øhall they cover them≈øelves with their Works, their Works are Works of Iniquity, I≈ø. 59.5, 6, 7.

Hence we find God is Ju≈øt, in puni≈øhing Man for his Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, and Man by his Folly hath brought him≈øelf and Po≈øterity to ruin, who through the Pride of his Concupi≈øcence, abode not in his Integrity, but in repining again≈øt God, hath brought him≈øelf and Po≈øterity, under Servitude to Sin, Mi≈øery, and Death.

Thus while with Rachel weeping for her Children, and refu≈øing to be Comforted, becau≈øe
they were not, Jer. 31.15. I was plunged in oppre≈ø≈øion of Thoughts, and heavily Lamenting, that ≈øo glorious a Fabrick of Gods Handy-work, as in the fir≈øt Creation, in Holine≈øs and Integrity ≈øhould be polluted by Sin, and defaced from the primitive Beauty, and as Mo≈øes pleading with God from the Arguments of his own Glory and Power, in behalf of his People of I≈ørael, Num. 14.11. to 17. heartily wi≈øhing, that glorious and fir≈øt Image might again be re≈øtored in Man, after the Image of him that Created it, I was led to that Scripture, My thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, ≈øaith the Lord, for as the Heavens are higher than the Earth, ≈øo are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts higher than your thoughts, I≈ø. 55.8, 9.

And while mu≈øing what the Spirit meant in the≈øe Expre≈ø≈øions, I was carryed back, to review the fatal Record of mans Condemnatory Sentence for his Rebellion, in which I found written, And I will put Enmity between thee and the Woman, and between thy Seed, and her Seed, it ≈øhall brui≈øe thy Head, and thou ≈øhalt brui≈øe his Heel, Gen. 3.15.

And being yet more in the dark, as to the meaning of that Scripture, I was led to that of Gods Covenant with Abraham, and I will E≈øtabli≈øh my Covenant between thee
and me, and thy Seed after thee, in their Generations for an everla≈øting Covenant, Gen. 17.7, 8. and to that other Word of God to Mo≈øes, I will rai≈øe them up a Prophet among≈øt their Brethren, like unto thee, and will put my words into his mouth, and he ≈øhall ≈øpeak unto them all the words which I have commanded him, Deut. 18.18. And being led a little further, to under≈øtand the meaning of this, I met with that Word of the Lord to David, by the Prophet Samuel, And thine Hou≈øe, and thy Kingdom ≈øhall be E≈øtabli≈øhed for ever before thee, and thy Throne ≈øhall be E≈øtabli≈øhed for ever, 2 Sam. 7.11, to 17.

And that of David him≈øelf, The Lord hath Sworn in Truth unto David, he will not turn from it, of the Fruit of thy Body will I ≈øet upon thy Throne, P≈ø. 132.11. And the Lord hath ≈øaid to my Lord, ≈øit thou at my Right Hand, until I make thine Enemies thy Foot-≈øtool, P≈ø. 110.1. and that other place of the ≈øame Prophet David, And thou wilt not leave my Soul in Hell, neither ≈øuffer thy Holy one to ≈øee Corruption, P≈ø. 16.10.

And thus being led to the view of the≈øe Scriptures, and being yet more Anxious to under≈øtand their meaning, I was at la≈øt, by the Ble≈ø≈øing of God, led to that of the ≈øecond
of the Acts, ver≈øe 22, to 37. And that of the 7th. of the Acts, And to the≈øe words, Of this mans Seed, hath God according to his promi≈øe, rai≈øed unto I≈ørael a Saviour, Acts 13.15, to 42.

By all which I found plainly laid open, that before the Foundations of the Earth were laid, 2 Tim. 1.9. God according to his own purpo≈øe, had provided the means of mans Redemption, and that all the foregoing Scriptures under the Old Te≈øtament, were Prophetical of his Eternal purpo≈øe, and good Will, and that in the fulne≈øs of time, he ≈øhould ≈øend one, even Je≈øus Chri≈øt, to take upon him the Nature of man, with whom God entred into an everla≈øting Covenant, and that for Sin, Sin ≈øhould be Condemned in the fle≈øh, and that Everla≈øting Covenant with Abraham, and the Prophets ≈øpoken of by Mo≈øes, and E≈øtabli≈øhing of Davids Throne for ever, are all meant of that Everlasting Covenant between God and Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the Second Adam, by which Covenant, Chri≈øt was to come in the fle≈øh, and ≈øuffer death as he did, and that he ≈øhould obtain Eternal Life, for all ≈øuch as ≈øhould believe in him, Jo. 3.16.

And thus being in≈øtructed, that the manifold promi≈øes and priviledges ≈øpoken of in the Old and New Te≈øtament, do belong to Believers, and that as well Salvation, as Faith, to lay hold on Je≈øus Chri≈øt, are freely of God as a gift,
Jam. 1.17. Hence I found the Truth of that of Gods Word, My thoughts are not your thoughts; our thoughts are narrow, and run only after the le≈ø≈øer things, and would de ≈øatisfied with the Re≈øtoration of man, to his fir≈øt E≈øtate in the fir≈øt Adam, and con≈øidering this new and Second Covenant, in the Second Adam, not only of things Temporal, but al≈øo of things Eternal, and that this Second Covenant is Everla≈øting, ≈øure, and not ≈øubject to the fatal Apo≈øtacy, as was that in the fir≈øt Adam.

And as in Contemplation of the Happy State of man, in his Fir≈øt Creation, the Heart was rai≈øed to rejoyce in God, and magnifie his goodne≈øs, and could not but take plea≈øure in ≈øo choice a Speculation, and as on reflection upon the di≈ømal and decayed condition of man, upon his degeneracy, the Soul mu≈øt needs be dejected with melancholy and grievous thoughts, how highly may the Soul be Elevated with Admiration, of that infinite love of God to mankind, in Chri≈øt Je≈øus, who hath in him, cho≈øen of the Seed of Abraham, before the Foundation of the World? Eph. 1.4, 5. having prede≈øtinated them unto the Adoption of Children to him≈øelf, and properly apply that of the Holy Prophet, Eye hath not ≈øeen, nor Ear heard, neither hath it entred into the Heart of Man (be≈øides thee O Lord) what good things he hath laid up for them, who wait on him, I≈ø. 64.4.

Thus, Chri≈øtian Reader, being led unto the meditation of the≈øe three material Concerns of mans everla≈øting condition, I have Collected the≈øe en≈øuing Sheets, in which I have fir≈øt con≈øidered mans condition in the Fir≈øt Creation, and Secondly under his Apo≈øtacy, wherein I have examined, that original Sin in Adam, in the ≈øeveral Ingredients thereof, and how far the Po≈øterity are guilty, and affected with the Evil Con≈øequences of the ≈øame; upon which are made ≈øome practical Inferences. Thirdly, I have con≈øidered the Covenant of grace in the Second Adam, wherein I have touched on all the Duties incumbent on Believers under that Covenant, and have met with all the emergent Ca≈øes of Affliction, incident to Believers, in the militant State, ≈øuch as ≈øpiritual de≈øertion, Afflictions by Sickne≈øs, Impri≈øonment, Poverty, Reproach, lo≈øs of, and being for≈øaken by Friends and Relations, and have collected and applyed the ≈øeveral promi≈øes to the re≈øpective ca≈øes, and in the clo≈øe, have examined the Duty of Chri≈øtian Patience, and Per≈øeverance, with the promi≈øes ≈øuitable thereunto; and la≈øtly, have drawn a large Series of Chri≈øtian Duties, and Truths, in ≈øhort Heads, with the Scriptural Proofs thereof; ≈øo as in two or three Pages, the marrow of the whole is comprehended; and as I dare averr in all Chri≈øtian Sincerity, the≈øe Sheets were only Collected for Private and Dome≈øtick u≈øe, without any intention
of ≈øending them to publick view, by which means they are in a more naked and rude dre≈øs, without the Curio≈øity of Eloquence or Artificial patching; and as by the importunity of ≈øome Friends, I was induced to ≈øend them abroad, I ≈øhall only de≈øire thus much in Chri≈øtian Charity, that thou maye≈øt believe that the≈øe are the effects of ≈øerious enquiry into the Holy Scriptures, with Meditation and Prayer, and narrowly ≈øearching into Truth, with what ≈øtrength I could obtain by grace; and that neither in O≈øtentation, or for ≈øecular ends they are ≈øent abroad, but in all Humility, if it may be, that others may find therein, that Light and E≈øtabli≈øhment in the way of God, which I hope I have, and ≈øhall find, and conceiving this to be a Duty, according to that of the Holy Apo≈øtle, Look not every Man on his own things, but every Man al≈øo on the things of another, Phil. 2.4. and that thou maye≈øt have the Truths of grace Sealed on thy Soul, and that Chri≈øt may dwell in thy Heart by Faith, and that being Rooted and Grounded in love, thou can≈øt be able to comprehend with all Saints, what is the breadth, and length, and depth, and height, and to know the love of Chri≈øt, which pa≈ø≈øeth knowledge, Eph. 3.17, 18, 19. and that thou may≈øt be filled with all the fulne≈øs of God; In all ≈øincerity is the earne≈øt Prayer of, thine in Chri≈øt Je≈øus our Lord.

div.head: THE Anatomy of Man.
div.p: SInce Man's Woful Apo≈øtacy from God, Sin is become ≈øo habitual, that the Cu≈øtom hath taken away the Con≈øcience of it, and Corruption is ≈øo conden≈øed in mens hearts, without the due ≈øen≈øe thereof, that unle≈øs upon gro≈øs out-breakings, little remor≈øe is expre≈ø≈øed for Sin, and Guilt for mo≈øt part is only owned from actual Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, and men do not charge them≈øelves with the guilt of Original Sin, as ≈øuppo≈øing that forreign to them, as coming from Adam's particular Act and Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, and take them≈øelves not to be accountable therefore, as being the ≈øingle Act of another; and if any thing of that guilt be owned, it is only by roate, and as coming from education, or the cu≈øtomary profe≈ø≈øion of Religion, without the due ≈øen≈øe or con≈øcience of the guilt; and in regard that Original ≈øin, hath more in it than one ≈øingle act, (though that one act of di≈øobedience was cau≈øe enough of all the mi≈øery that followed) and that the con≈øequence of that di≈øobedience, hath fallen upon, and concerneth all the Po≈øterity of Adam, we ≈øhall therefore con≈øider,
Fir≈øt, What Original Sin was in Adam.
Secondly, How far the Po≈øterity of Adam are therein concerned, or chargeable and affected with it.
Thirdly, We ≈øhall make ≈øome practical Inferences and U≈øes from thence.

Fir≈øt, If we con≈øider Adam, the fir≈øt and root of all Mankind, that he was of God created after the Likene≈øs of God, in his Image, Gen. 1.26, 27, 28. and at his fir≈øt Creation had power and command given him to increa≈øe and multiply, and ≈øubdue and have dominion, over the Fi≈øh of the Sea, the Fowls of the Air, and every thing that moveth on the Earth, (under re≈øtriction from eating of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil) with a penalty upon eating thereof, that he ≈øhould ≈øurely dye. Gen. 2.15, 16, 17. Thus Man made after the Likene≈øs of God, and in the Image of God, let us examine what this Likene≈øs and Image was; The Holy Apo≈øtle Paul tells us, that it was Righteou≈øne≈øs and true Holine≈øs, Eph. 4.24.
The ≈øame Apo≈øtle el≈øewhere informs us, that it was in Knowledge, after the Image of him that Created him, Col. 3.10.

By the≈øe words of Righteou≈øne≈øs, true Holine≈øs, and Knowledge, we may under≈øtand, that Adam in his fir≈øt Creation, was endowed with all ≈øuitable faculties of the Mind, to under≈øtand the Nature of all Bea≈øts, Fowls, Fi≈øhes, creeping Things, and Vegetatives, how to u≈øe and apply them to his own u≈øe, and govern them in order to their ≈øubjection to him≈øelf, and congruity among them≈øelves; as we find by Gods bringing the Creatures to Adam, to ve≈øt him with Soveraignty over them, and that he might expre≈øs his faculty of under≈øtanding, by giving to them names, Gen. 2.19, 20. and as ≈øome naturali≈øts ob≈øerve, he gave to them names ≈øignificant or expre≈ø≈øive of their nature, which implied his Knowledge of their ≈øeveral Natures, from that primitive Knowledge given to him in his fir≈øt Creation.

By Righteou≈øne≈øs rendred in the Latine Ju≈øtice,
as it is the Likene≈øs, and Image of God, we mu≈øt under≈øtand all integrity of Mind, leading to what is right, and forbearing what is wrong.

By true Holine≈øs, we mu≈øt under≈øtand, all purity of Mind, Will and Affections in Sincerity and Truth, to affect only and de≈øire what is ju≈øt, pure, holy, and good, and to ≈øhun all Thoughts, Affections, Actions, or Purpo≈øes to the contrary, as God is of purer Eyes than can behold Iniquity.

And by that Knowledge of God, according to the Image of him that created him, we mu≈øt under≈øtand effectual and ≈øufficient knowledge, not only of things natural, but al≈øo of Spiritual Truths, by which man was made effectually capable to under≈øtand, and to do good, to ab≈øtain from, and re≈øi≈øt evil.

Thus Man being compo≈øed, in ≈øuch excellent frame, capable to under≈øtand all things, as well of God him≈øelf, as of the Creatures, and that he had his Being of God, and ≈øufficiently under≈øtood the Terms under which he was confined to his Allegiance and Obedience to God, and the con≈øequence of his Di≈øobedience, and there being given to him entire Integrity, not tainted by any pollution, or di≈øabled by infirmities, in full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all ≈øecular enjoyments, with the knowledge of the glorious ≈øoveraignty of God, and Maje≈øty in the Creation, ≈øufficient to delight him≈øelf in God, and glorifie his Maker in the Station he had placed him. If David after the Apo≈øtacy, when for Sin the World was degenerated, and brought under the Cur≈øe and Bondage, did then admire Mans Excellency, Power, and Glory, how much more when in Mans Integrity, unity of the Creation, without Enmity, Jarring, or Di≈øcord, Emulation or Contention? the Morning Stars ≈øang together, Job 38.7. and all the Sons of God ≈øhouted for Joy. How had the fir≈øt Man rea≈øon
to cry out; How excellent art thou Lord in all the Earth? And what is Man; that thou remembre≈øt him, or the Son of Man, that thou art mindful of him? And what rea≈øon had he? And how much had it been his and the happine≈øs of all Po≈øterities, to have ≈øate down contentedly, in admiration and obedience of God, and in quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all created enjoyments, and ≈øubjection of the Creatures to him?

Thus Man Created in Righteou≈øne≈øs, true Holine≈øs, and Knowledge, after the Image of God, made Lord of all the Creatures, and in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, having ≈øufficient knowledge to under≈øtand his Duty and Intere≈øt, and to know the advantage of Obedience, and con≈øequence of breach of Duty, breaks the Chain of his Obedience; and eats the forbidden fruit, Gen. 3.6.

Whereupon God in his Ju≈øtice, according to his Promi≈øe, and Terms of Mans fir≈øt Creation, deprives Man of his Soveraignty over the Creatures, puts Enmity between Man and the Creatures, and accur≈øeth Man, and the Earth for his ≈øake, Gen. 3.14. to the end.

This being the Matter of fact in Mans Creation, under the Penal Law, and his Breach, and Rebellion again≈øt God, and the puni≈øhment of his di≈øobedience, we come next to examine the nature of this fir≈øt and original ≈øin, and con≈øider whether it con≈øi≈øted only in this ≈øingle Act, of eating of the Tree of Knowledge; or what other ≈øins were, or are complicated in it.

If we con≈øider Man as truly endowed by God, with Knowledge, Righteou≈øne≈øs, and true Holine≈øs, and under the Prohibition of a Penal Law, we ≈øhall find all the ≈øins committed and di≈øcovered in after Ages, under the growth of Corruption, to have been in that tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion.

Fir≈øt, That wilful breach of Gods Law and Sin,
cannot be palliate, under the excu≈øe of the ≈øin of Ignorance, for that mans knowledge was ≈øtrong and ≈øufficiently clear, to under≈øtand good and evil, and in re≈øpect there was a po≈øitive prohibition again≈øt ≈øuch offence, it mu≈øt imply knowledge, and therefore makes it a wilful breach and offence again≈øt a known Law.

Secondly, It cannot be called the Sin of Infirmity or ≈øurprize, as Adam would have excu≈øed him≈øelf, by the Womans giving of the fruit to him, and the Womans Apology of the Serpents beguiling her; for that they were foretold, that they ≈øhould not Eat of that Fruit, and forbid the eating thereof, under the Penalty of Death, Gen. 3.12, 13. and that the knowledge they had of good and evil, and that to break the Commandment of God was evil it ≈øelf, although it had not been under the Penalty expre≈ø≈øed, and therefore having in them≈øelves ≈øufficient knowledge to under≈øtand, and ≈øtrength to defeat and re≈øi≈øt the force and arguments of Satans In≈øinuations, this Sin was a vehement and bold pre≈øumption again≈øt the Ju≈øtice and Authority of God.

Thirdly, This Sin was of the greate≈øt Pride and Ambition imaginable, for that God had endowed Man with knowledge ≈øufficient in every re≈øpect, to make him happy, in under≈øtanding all things to complete his ≈øatisfaction and delight in God, and the Creatures; neverthele≈øs upon Satans In≈øinuation, that, by eating of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, they ≈øhould become more knowing and be like Gods, knowing Good and Evil, they wilfully in the Pride and Ambition of their Hearts, lu≈øted after knowledge to be equal with God, and by di≈øobedience broke Gods Law.

Fourthly, This Sin was of greate≈øt unbelief and impeachment of Gods Truth and Ju≈øtice, in believing Satans Lye, (you ≈øhall not ≈øurely die,) Gen. 3.4. and not believing
Gods word, thou ≈øhalt ≈øurely die. Whereby to their own ruin, and ruin of their, Po≈øterity they yeilded to a deceitfully, and did not obey the Truth and righteou≈øne≈øs, Gen. 2.17.

Fifthly, This eating of the Tree of Knowledge, implyed the greate≈øt Murmuring, Repining, and Ingratitude, for that God had given to Man, the U≈øe of and Dominion over all the Creatures and had only re≈øerved one ≈øingle Tree, with a Prohibition from meddling with it; neverthele≈øs man is not Content, but mu≈øt have all, not remembring, or willfully forgetting, that he had his beginning and being of God, and what he had, was of and from him, and that he had what was ≈øufficient to make him happy; yet was his Covetou≈øne≈øs without bounds.

Sixthly, This Sin was of the greate≈øt Sloth, imprudence, and inadvertence, in that while God had endowed Man with Knowledge, Righteou≈øne≈øs, and Holine≈øs, when Satan did acco≈øt him, with a Ly, to break the Command, he ≈øhould have reflected on the Righteou≈øne≈øs and Hoilne≈øs of God, that it was impo≈ø≈øible for God to Lie, and thereby ≈øhould have re≈øi≈øted Satans Sugge≈øtions, founded on a Ly from the Holyne≈øs and Goodne≈øs of God in giving man all things; he ≈øhould have rea≈øoned that it was not ju≈øt in him to murmur at his plea≈øure in mans being re≈øtrained from ≈øome thing, and upon Satans fir≈øt Sugge≈øtion of a Ly again≈øt God, he ≈øhould not have li≈øtned further to him‚ñ™ but re≈øted in the Credit of Gods truth and continued in his Obedience.

Seventhly, From the Method of Committing this Sin, all manner of Sin ≈øeems to be employed in it the Text ≈øaith, And when the Woman ≈øaw that the Tree was good for Food, and that it was plea≈øant to the Eyes, and a Tree to be de≈øired to make one
wi≈øe: She took of the Fruit thereof, and did eat, and gave al≈øo to her Husband with her, and he did eat, Gen. 3.6.

From hence we ≈øee when Satan by a lying Sugge≈øtion had tampered with the Woman, ay and got her to li≈øten to his temptation, from her ambition of (being as Gods) ≈øhe lets her thoughts out to a further ≈øurvey of the apparent excellencies and advantages to be had in the eating of that fruit, and thus ambition kindleth lu≈øt, and one lu≈øt begetteth another, ≈øo the heart ≈øwelling with ambition of further Knowledge, and that ambition runs to the Eyes, and from the Eyes to the Sen≈øual Appetite, and thus the whole Ma≈øs is tainted and defiled, and let out to the gluttinous poy≈øoning of the Soul to the Rebellion of Di≈øobedience.

This ≈øeems to be that ≈øame thing which the Apo≈øtle calls the Lu≈øt of the Fle≈øh, the Lu≈øt of the Eyes, and the Pride of Life. Which is an entire Ma≈øs of all pollution, ≈øo that it was not only the eating of that fruit which was the Sin only, but the Infection that was got into the Heart and Affections, whereby the goodly frame of Righteou≈øne≈øs, Holyne≈øs, and true Knowledge became all tainted and infected with the deceitful Appetites and Lu≈øts of the Fle≈øh, 1 Joh. 2.15, 16.

Fir≈øt, By di≈øtru≈øting of God, and then by a Covetous lu≈øting after what was ≈øet apart from them by Gods prohibition, and ≈øo breaking the limits of Obedience, lets the Lu≈øt ≈øwing after a carnal propen≈øion or forwardne≈øs to ≈øatiate their de≈øires, and thus di≈øorders the righteous frame of Ju≈øtice, Holyne≈øs and Knowledge, lately erected by God in them, ≈øo that this Sin was not only that actual and only act of eating the fruit, but the Corruption of the whole faculties run into di≈øorder from
God, expre≈ø≈øed by that rebellious act of eating the forbidden Fruit of the Tree of Knowledge.

This al≈øo ≈øeems to be proved and explained in many places of Scripture, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the Apo≈øtle Paul, I had not known Sin, but by the Law: I had not known lu≈øt, except the Law had ≈øaid thou ≈øhalt not Covet; Rom. 7.7. Where by the word Lu≈øt rendred mo≈øt properly in the Original (Concupi≈øcence) and the word Covet there, Exod. 20.17. is properly meant a de≈øire of what is more than our own, and allowable in Ju≈øtice, and in that place, For the Iniquity of his Covetou≈øne≈øs, I≈øa. 57.17. Where by Covetou≈øne≈øs is meant the lu≈øtful Inclinations, and by the Apo≈øtle in that place, Rom. 7.7. By lu≈øts he means not ≈øo much the polluted actions of the Fle≈øh as the polluted fountain of them, Non pravas Cupiditates ≈øed illarum fontem; and the Soul is well called Sedes Nativae illius labis, the ≈øeat of that Natural Corruption, and this ≈øeems likewi≈øe to be confirmed by that Scripture and God ≈øaw that the wickedne≈øs of man was greater in the Earth, and that every Imagination of the thoughts of his heart was evil and only evil continually, Gen 6.5. Where God chargeth mans heart with this Sin as being the Fountain of the Corruption.

That of the P≈øalmi≈øt, The Fool hath ≈øaid in his heart there is no God, P≈øal. 14.1. Seems to be to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, for none were openly ≈øuch profe≈ø≈øed Athei≈øts as to deny the being of God, but the Prophanity of their Conver≈øation leads the P≈øalmi≈øt to charge them with denying of God, whereby he chargeth the heart with the pollution and brings the act of Sin as In≈øtance and proof of it.

Chri≈øt him≈øelf al≈øo in that Scripture But tho≈øe things which come out of the mouth, come from the heart,
